unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Yahtzee Probability
question_text:
In the game of Yahtzee, a player tosses $5$, fair, $6$-sided dice while trying to form various combinations like three of a kind (for example: $4, 4, 4, 5, 1$), or a full house (for example: $2, 2, 2, 6, 6$). If all five dice show the same number (for example: $3, 3, 3, 3, 3$), the player has rolled a Yahtzee.
How would you calculate the probability that a player will roll Yahtzee on their first roll of the dice?
solution:
To roll a Yahtzee, a player could roll five $1$'s or five $2$'s or five $3$'s or five $4$'s or five $5$'s or five $6$'s.

$p(\text{five $1$'s})$ can be found using the multiplication rule. That is:

$$p(1, 1, 1, 1, 1) = \left( \frac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) \cdot \left( \frac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) \cdot \left( \frac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) \cdot \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) \cdot \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) ={ \left( \frac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) }^{ 5 }$$

$p(\text{five $2$'s})$ is calculated exactly the same way and produces the same answer as $p(\text{five $1$'s})$.

In fact:

$$p(\text{five $
1$'s})=p(\text{five $2$'s})=p(\text{five $3$'s})=p(\text{five $4$'s})=p(\text{five $5$'s})=p(\text{five $6$'s})$$

Therefore:

$$p(\text{Yahtzee})={ \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) }^{ 5 }\cdot 6$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect as it does not account for all five dice being rolled. It simply represents the probability of rolling a specific (unknown) number when a single dice is tossed.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because it does not account for the fact that a Yahtzee could be achieved by rolling any one of the six possible outcomes on every dice. This represents the probability of rolling $5$ dice which result in the same specific (unknown) number, such as rolling five $1$'s.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. We cannot simply multiply the probability of rolling a specific (unknown) number by $5$ to account for the fact that five dice are being tossed.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Although the actual probability is quite close to zero, there is still a very small probability that a player will toss a Yahtzee on their first roll of the dice.
